Posts.Content: Oh AnnJac, I’m so ready reading your email! Im so pleased you made decision, and have listened to your body. I can imagine you do feel all turbulent- but as you say you can focus your mind and days on healing.  I’m thinking of you and CONGRATULATIONS on finishing your chemo!! Sending up fireworks in my mind.  Sending big squishy hugs back at you.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hey everyone, Did you find that you had sleeplessness after Taxol? I've only had 1 dose and while I did have a sleeping tablet on day1 as they gave me steroids, since then my sleep has been TERRIBLE. Is this a common thing? I guess it could be stress stopping me, but usually Im a good sleeper. Any advice appreciated!xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Karen 234, Thanks for your message! Maybe the sleeplessness is stress and this whole journey just taking its toll.  Im going to try a “sleepy tea” tonight, fingers crossed.  Hugs to all and HUGE CONGRATULATIONS, Bluebell22! I’m so chuffed to hear the news. Simply brilliant!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi @Mary4, Thanks for your message- I’m sorry you’re struggling with sleep too. My GP gave me a weaker sleeping tablet but I don’t want to become reliant on them, esp as I have 11 more doses (weekly) of Taxol to go!  I think part of it is worrying about side effects esp neuropathy, plus the joint and muscle aches. Enjoy the good week! I found on my good weeks on EC I made up for the lack of eating in the bad week  ...ah well!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Mrs50, When I had those injections I set two alarms (one to get it out of the fridge absolutely one to get injected!). That probably sounds so dumb and obvious but without alarms I don’t know what I’d get up to (still applies now!). I was the same- felt pain in my long bones about 6 days after the injection, but it was manageable with paracetamol. I hope it all goes smoothly for you!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Oh TheScriptFan!!!!! CONGRATULATIONS!!!! What brilliant news, well done hip hip hooray. I’m so thrilled to read this, amazing news before Christmas. You hung in there and had a really tough go. Ah, so pleased to read this today.  Big hugs!!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hey all, I'm back on the chemo-train, too. I've finished my 4 doses of EC (brutal ) and am now in the 3-week gap between last EC and starting Taxol (12 doses). I'm feel SO over this journey (since July '17 I've had 4 surgeries plus other chemo last year, that didn't work) and I'm scared of the Taxol side-effects, namely the neuropathy /loss of feeling in my feet etc. I know not everyone gets that but for some reason its terrifying me. Would love any ideas/suggestions on ANYTHING I can do to prevent that?
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: MERRY CHRISTMAS LADIES! We may be a bit battered and bruised, but we’re fighting for a better 2019. cheers to you and your bravery,  to your loved ones and cheerleaders to the sleepless nights and anxious days we’ve seen them through and are still here May you find peace today.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Oh thank you Ariesgirl! Thats so kind of you- don’t worry about the tech, we can google! I’ll def plan this, and chat to my oncologist when I see him. I’m so terrified, it’s weird- I think I’m just exhausted.  So pleased you’re through so much of the poop!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Dear AnnJac, I'm so pleased to hear there's been a response to the chemo- making all that poop it worthwhile. I understand that a full mastectomy sounds daunting- but I found last year when I had two mastectomies (one preventative) that while they are big surgeries, in comparison I'd say they're easier than chemo.  I'm sorry you cant have the surgeries closer to home though. On a visual level I think you're right- new designer boobies here you come ;) Will be thinking of you on the 12th- last one must sound good to write!  Big hugs!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hey Daisydoo38,  I have been coldcapping (last year with 4 cycles of TC and this year with 4 cycles of EC). While I’ve kept most of my hair, I have lost some hair with each cycle on my crown where the ColdCap didn’t have good contact with my head. The hair loss started about Day16 or so? I didn’t have pain on my scalp thoug,h so I can’t comment on the relationship to losing any... There’s no guarantees with ColdCap sadly, but hopefully it’ll minimise your hair loss. Fingers crossed for you!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hey wigan59, great new re ColdCap! Re the potential delay to your next dose- it’s not uncommon for a dose to be delayed, but if you’re feeling concerned please talk to your BCN or oncologist so they can reassure you.  Big hugs!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi AnnJac, Oh I’m so pleased you have the surgical plan! It helps doesn’t it, to know what’s ahead rather than it being the unknown. I hope the fatigue resolves itself- it’s a kicker isn’t it? I’m trying as much as I can to nap or rest each afternoon (when life allows!)... Try and keep faith that your body wants to heal, so you just have to support that process as best you can. Good luck with the weightless- I know what you mean about sweet things only being palatable! Hugs.
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Coley1993, and Ruby Rose i think the longlasting anti-nausea is called Akynzeo I had it and it and while it DEFINITELY helped, it also causes constipation so it’s worth having a management plan (e.g. start Movicol and Docusate the day before chemo and ongoing to prevent issues forming). Hope this helps! Big hugs!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Sept78, I’m so sorry you’re going through all of this, that sounds painful and tough- esp as you have more to go. I definitely think you should discuss a PICC or portacath insertion with your oncologist, as it does give the veins a break. I had a portacath inserted before my chemo began... I TOTALLY get how you don’t want another procuedure, but I found this one was a breeze in comparison to all the rest (way easier than my mastectomies and chemo!). So it’s worth having a talk to see what’s possible? Also, please don’t apologise for moaning!!! We have to get out the ranting and raving, you’d go mad otherwise. Hang in there... this is a tough road,  but you’ve got this. big hugs!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Oh Teenytaters, I’m so sorry that you’re having such a tough time. Chemo IS totally poop and you’re doing amazingly, even though it doesn’t feel like it. As much as you can, just focus on ONE day at a time. Just this dose, and the days of recovery. It does help- you can’t do more than that, and thinking forward to other doses doesn’t help.  Also, be open with your team about every single side effect. They can help manage them to make it easier- don’t be shy.  As for hair- I feel you! I’m cold capping too- it’s awful. But hang in there, and ensure the person putting on the Cap ensures the right size and a good fit- where there is a gap between skin and cap there is hair loss.  Hang in there babe - we’re cheering you on!
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hello NiceCuppa, Well, here I am oversharing! But I may have had a similar issue- it was caused by constipation (sorry) that led to a weird indigestion where I felt that I had a balloon in my stomach and it felt like I could barely eat or swallow. Does that sound familiar? In any case, for me once I'd sorted the constipation, the indigestion sorted itself. But as always- maybe call the onco suite and see if they have any suggestions? (eg could it be a normal sore throat from someone who had it and visited?). Whatever it is- i hope it resolves soon. Take care of yourself!!
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi MooCoo, Just wondering- have you had the white blood cell boosting injections? Aka Neulasta or filgrastim... they def cause bone ache, and often in the long bones/hips etc. In my case the best painkiller was paracetamol and not ibuprofen/naproxen.  Not sure if that’s helpful but thought I’d mention it! Good luck and all the best.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Devon Dumpling, i found my hair started growing back within a few weeks- but it’s a bit frizzy in texture compared to my usual hair! I was recommended a spray by my hairdresser  (Kérastase, Specifique) which seems to be helpful. But there seems to be a few other products that help (as does taking collagen).  I don’t know about the photosensitivity - will be interested to learn more! Big hugs and well done for hanging in there.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi all, I just popped on to say I’m done with chemo- last dose was 01March. Hard to believe it is done with, felt like it was going to drag on forever. I’m so tired, but not beaten down and now I have 2 weeks to recover before radiotherapy starts. Will celebrate when I feel up to it! I want to thank you all for the advice and comaraderie- it’s been so valuable and has helped me through such a dark time. I wish every one of you the smoothest path possible throughout your chemo and am sending every best wish and lots of very gentle hugs.
Posts.Title: ***March 2019 Breast Cancer Chem Chat ***

Posts.Content: Hi Tiger, As another newbie starting chemo in Aug (17th) I've no sage advice to offer you, but wanted to say I'll be thinking of you as I do mine, and will hope for the best for you. The people on this forum have been so kind to me in the pasts few days and I hope I can be helpful in future!
Posts.Title: New chemo starter

Posts.Content: Hi Maz73, Yes I'd suggest the codiene (but do check it's not contra-indicated!) as it made it far easier for me. Fingers crossed it helps you! My "support team" know that there's times I'm tired or can't focus, so I made sure they brought a book or work in with them if I need downtime. I listen to podcasts too- something for the brain to engage with but you can have your eyes closed (also a signal to the supporters for quiet time!) All the best to you (and everyone!!)
Posts.Title: New Cold Cap procedure (suggestions to help)

Posts.Content: Afternoon all! I'm just home from the hospital and have had 2 chemo cycles now both under the new Cold Cap procedure. For me both were about 3.5hrs, which is pretty intense. Apparently the new recommendation is: -30min prior -duration of chemo -90min post-chemo I tried some strategies that really helped- while it wasn't a pleasure to do it (understatement), the things below made it far more bearable. 1. Take 2 paracetamol and codiene 30min before the start of the cooling. (* please ask if this is OK and not and there are no interactions with your chemo/other meds!)  2. Have two heat pads - one under your back, high up and one on your chest/stomach etc.  (could bring in hot water bottles?) 3. Hot drinks- all throughout the cooling. I had soup and tea (bonus as they help with hydration) I think the cumulative impact of all of these things really helped. Also- I told my oncologist about the new cooling procedure and they weren't aware- so it's definitely worth mentioning it. Any other suggestions? Good luck to everyone on this mad journey!
Posts.Title: New Cold Cap procedure (suggestions to help)

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, oh I totally understand. I debated giving up Cold Cap too, but honestly it was bearable with the  codiene-paracetamol combo and the extra warming options. I used a bathroom to rinse off the leave-in conditioner before I went home (wearing a cap!) as those icicles weren't pleasant.  ive had some thinning :( hoping it'll all be worth it.
Posts.Title: New Cold Cap procedure (suggestions to help)

Posts.Content: Oh thanks gratefulkate! So sweet of you to remember.  Just home now- will start a new chain about the cold-cap as I have some good strategies and want to share them! Feeling OK now, but Im hopped up on steroids, so lets wait and see...
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hi Star 67 Please can you tell me more about the "wig bank"? Thanks!!
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, I've had 1/4 cycles of TC, my 2nd is on 07Sep. Feeling pretty anxious about it as I'm finally feeling more human after dose #1... re cold-cap, I had to wear it for 4 bloody unpleasant hours. But- I've still got my hair today (fingers crossed that stays!) . I took 2 paracetamol beforehand, which did nothing. However I asked if I could take codiene this time and was told it was fine (no interaction with the TC chemo). Will report back if that helps at all! good luck everyone
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hey LucasJack, talk you your onco nurse re painkillers pre ColdCap. Mine gave ok'd taking Codeine and paracetamol prior to chemp, to help. just a suggestion! All the very best- will think of you and the other Sep chemo ladies today!
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: I'm so pleased you're home now Sylvie64! Fingers crossed that's a one-off. I've started a cool cap suggestions thread under the main Breast Cancer group as it's much busier than the under 50s group- hope it helps!
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hi All, Well I'm coming out of the woods after my 2nd dose... did anyone else find the second was both better (less anxiety than the 1st) but worse (more dread as you know what's to come)? I also found my mood dipped VERY low, really sad days during this one. Just feeling very hopeless in the face of more chemo to come and possibly radiotx, and then more surgery. Other than that, the usual suspects of nausea, mouth sores, intense fatigue and bone marrow pain (from the Neublasta). I needed more anti-nausea tablets this time vs dose 1. I continue to lose some hair, developed a rather unsexy bald patch on my crown :(  Still, I think its where the cold cap didnt reach, so will keep using it- even though its awful to go through, sometimes it feels like one cold capping is one of the only areas in which I do have some control, so will keep at it. I hope everyone has the best possible Friday. Good luck to anyone getting their dose today!  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Hi Ceili, I'm so sorry to hear the experience was tough with Neulasta. I had pain as a Neulasta side effect after dose 1, too. I struggled with it for a day (I was an idiot, I thought it was nerve pain and painkillers wouldn't work ). Once I took painkillers the pain was more manageable, and the pain wasn't as bad after dose 2. Sending a hug!
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *

Posts.Content: Thanks star67- will def be sharing that link!! Ive got my 3rd dose next week- the dread is already creeping up.  Wishing everyone in the chemo club all the best for their next round...
Posts.Title: * * * SEPTEMBER BREAST CANCER CHEMO CLUB * * *
